newsitem.title: USA: High cost alumina producers may shut-Kaiser.
newsitem.headline: High cost alumina producers may shut-Kaiser.

text.p: Producers of alumina above $150 per tonne may be forced to shut as new, low cost producers enter the market over coming years, Peter McIntosh, director of business development at Kaiser Aluminum Corp, said.

"All of the new capacity coming on stream is low cost and this pushes high cost plants up the cost curve. If uncorrected, they face the prospect of shutting," McIntosh told Metal Bulletin's Bauxite and Alumina seminar.

Australia dominated in the low cost end of alumina production, producing 13.5 million tonnes a year, by far the biggest single producer, followed by North and Latin America at 6.5 million tonnes respectively.
Some two tonnes of alumina are needed to make one tonne of aluminum. Spot alumina prices are about $200 a tonne at present.
Aluminum prices, although highly cyclical, were trending around 70 cents a pound and rising only slowly because aluminum is a mature industry.

Between 1997 and 1999, the aluminum market needed to grow 3.5 percent to remain in balance, with no major increases in auto and housing demand seen and significant restocking was unlikely, McIntosh said.
The Western alumina sector was operating at 96 to 98 percent of nameplate capacity, and idled capacity will be able to meet any increase in demand until 1999.
Alumina refineries must be competitive at $150 a tonne or less in down cycles, McIntosh said. Even at $150 a tonne, half of the world's alumina capacity will not be making money.
"To survive, you need to be in the bottom half of the cost curve," McIntosh said.
When capital costs are included, even fewer alumina plants were profitable.
"Cyclical demand and price, and slow growth are here to stay," McIntosh said. "We have to learn to live with it and I don't believe we have."
